factoid: Bolkónski asked, 'Where is Natásha?'
Bolkónski added, 'Excuse me!'
Bolkónski turned to the baron.
Bolkónski said, 'We will finish this conversation elsewhere—at a ball one must dance.'
Bolkónski stepped forward in the direction Pierre indicated.
The despairing, dejected expression of Natásha’s face caught Bolkónski's eye.
Bolkónski recognized Natásha.
Bolkónski guessed Natásha's feelings.
Bolkónski saw that it was Natásha's debut.
Bolkónski remembered Natásha's conversation at the window.
Bolkónski approached Countess Rostóva with pleasure on his face.
Countess Rostóva said, 'Allow me to introduce you to my daughter.'
Countess Rostóva had heightened color.
Prince Andrew said, 'I have the pleasure of being already acquainted, if the countess remembers me.'
Prince Andrew bowed low and courteously.
Prince Andrew's bow belied Perónskaya’s remarks about his rudeness.
Prince Andrew approached Natásha and held out his arm to grasp her waist before completing his invitation.
Prince Andrew asked Natásha to waltz.
Natásha's expression prepared for despair or rapture suddenly brightened into a happy, grateful, childlike smile.
Natásha seemed to say, 'I have long been waiting for you,' by the smile that replaced the threatened tears.
Natásha raised her hand to Prince Andrew’s shoulder.
The second couple entered the circle.
Prince Andrew was one of the best dancers of his day.
Natásha danced exquisitely.
Natásha's little feet in her white satin dancing shoes worked swiftly, lightly, and independently of herself.
Natásha's face beamed with ecstatic happiness.
Natásha's slender bare arms and neck were not beautiful compared to Hélène’s.
Natásha's shoulders looked thin and her bosom undeveloped.
Hélène seemed hardened by a varnish left by thousands of looks that scanned her person.
Natásha was like a girl exposed for the first time, who would have felt very much ashamed had she not been assured that this was absolutely necessary.
Prince Andrew liked dancing.
Prince Andrew wished to escape as quickly as possible from the political and clever talk everyone addressed to him.
Prince Andrew wished to break up the circle of restraint he disliked, caused by the Emperor’s presence.
Prince Andrew danced.
Prince Andrew chose Natásha because Pierre pointed her out to him and because she was the first pretty girl who caught his eye.
Prince Andrew scarcely had embraced Natásha's slender supple figure and felt her stirring close to him and smiling near him.
Prince Andrew's wine of her charm rose to his head.
Prince Andrew felt himself revived and rejuvenated after leaving Natásha.
Prince Andrew stood breathing deeply and watching other dancers after leaving Natásha.
After Prince Andrew, Borís asked Natásha for a dance.
The aide-de-camp who had opened the ball asked Natásha for a dance.
Several other young men asked Natásha for a dance.
Natásha remained dancing all evening.
Natásha did not notice what occupied everyone else.
Natásha did not notice the Emperor talked a long time with the French ambassador.
Natásha did not notice how particularly gracious he was to a certain lady.
Natásha did not notice that Prince So-and-so and So-and-so did and said this and that.
Natásha did not notice that Hélène had great success and was honored by special attention of So-and-so.
Natásha did not see the Emperor.
Natásha only noticed that the Emperor had gone because the ball became livelier after his departure.
For one of the merry cotillions before supper, Prince Andrew was again Natásha's partner.
Prince Andrew reminded Natásha of their first encounter in the Otrádnoe avenue.
Prince Andrew reminded Natásha of how she had been unable to sleep that moonlight night.
Prince Andrew told Natásha how he had involuntarily overheard her.
Natásha blushed at that recollection.
Natásha tried to excuse herself as if there had been something to be ashamed of in what Prince Andrew had overheard.
Prince Andrew liked meeting someone there not of the conventional society stamp.
Natásha was surprised, delighted, shy, and made mistakes in speaking French.
Prince Andrew behaved with special care and tenderness with Natásha.
Prince Andrew sat beside Natásha and talked of the simplest and most unimportant matters.
Prince Andrew admired Natásha's shy grace.
In the middle of the cotillion, after completing one of the figures, Natásha was returning to her seat when another dancer chose her.
Natásha was tired and panting.
Natásha thought of declining.
Natásha immediately put her hand gaily on the man's shoulder.
Natásha smiled at Prince Andrew.
